awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated memristor neural networks for in-situ analysis of intracellular neuronal recordings
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to detect and analyze individual neuron spiking patterns over large areas will have profound impacts on neuroscience and medicine, as it allows the functions of the brain to be directly mapped to underlying neuron activities and enables precise brain disease detection and drug developments. However, although recent advances in neuroprobes such as nanoelectrode arrays make it possible to pick up signals from single neurons, scaling the systems to thousands and possibly millions of neuron sites is not practical due the enormous resources and time required to digitize, store and analyze the vast amount of data. This proposal aims to precisely address these challenges by integrating an artificial neural network on the nanoelectrode array, such that cell signals picked up by the electrodes are directly processed by the artificial neural network, and only the processed, "useful" data need to be amplified and transmitted, allowing real-time analysis with very low power. Undergraduate and graduate students will be trained to obtain state-of-the-art nanotechnology and neuroengineering techniques. Knowledge and techniques developed during research will be incorporated into course materials and other types of publications to allow cross pollination for students among different disciplines and broad dissemination to the general public. 
The proposed new neural recording system will offer unparalleled spatial resolution and processing capabilities, where high density and highly sensitive nanoelectrode arrays are integrated with a memristor-based artificial neural network that allows real time signal processing. By optimizing and utilizing internal dynamic ionic processes in the memristors, the artificial network can be directly driven by the spike trains from biological neurons without amplification or other pre-processing, where responses from the memristor network can be used to analyze temporal patterns in the neuron spikes and to connect detected neuronal activity with functions of the biological networks. The tightly coupled memristor network with the biological network can further allow functions in the biological system to be directly mapped on the electrical system, and potentially lead to future neural prosthesis and augmentation applications. New materials, devices, and networks will be developed, along with new recording and computing strategies that broaden the impact of the proposed project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project between University of Michigan and Harvard University seeks to demonstrate the application of memristor-based reservoir computing in analyzing biological neuronal recording data. As an integral part of this effort, the Harvard team aims to drive a memristor with network intracellular recording traces -- which we obtain with our CMOS neuroelectronic interface and rat cortical neurons cultured on top -- in such a way that the memristor with spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) can find time-correlated recording traces, and thus connected neurons. This memristor-driven physical method to extract neuronal connections from electrophysiological recording data contrasts the software method to do the same task in the sense that the former may take a much shorter time if fully developed. 

In the prior reporting period, we developed an HfO2/TiO2 memristor, and stared working on finding connected neurons with 16 neuronal recording traces. In this prior effort, we drove the memristor with biphasic square pulse converted from neuronal actional potentials (APs). In the present reporting period, we have newly engineered biphasic sawtooth voltage spikes (to convert neuronal APs to) and used them to drive the memristor. This is to optimize the memristor's STDP behavior so that its STDP curve can be better aligned with the time-correlations of neuronal recording traces, so that the STDP can more effectively extract neuronal connections. In this new approach, the memristor has found 55 out of 61 true neuronal connections from a total of 108 neuronal recording traces. 

These advances -- in-depth engineering of the memristor behavior for physical imprinting of neuronal connections -- address the intellectual merit of this project. The broader impacts are addressed by the importance of the neuronal connection mapping technique we are developing in both fundamental neuroscience and machine intelligence and by the interdisciplinary training of researchers across device fabrication, the physics of analog resistive memory, data analysis of electrophysiological recording, and neuromorphic engineering. 

Technical details: 

Figure 1a schematically shows two sawtooth voltage spikes that drive the two terminals of the memristor with a time difference Δt. The resulting STDP (memristor conductance change ΔG vs Δt) measured is shown as blue data. In a pair of strongly connected neurons chosen from our intracellular recording data, an AP fired by a presynaptic neuron tends to elicit an AP in a postsynaptic neuron well within 20 ms. Thus if we compress the time scale of the recording by 100 times, the time delay ΔT from a presynaptic AP to a postsynaptic AP in a strongly connected neuronal pair would tend to fall in the positive STDP time window (0 ~ 0.2 ms). Indeed as we overlay the histogram of ΔT (after 100´ time compression) from 126 strongly connected neuronal pairs (Fig. 1a, gray) onto the STDP data (Fig. 1a, blue), more than 90% of ΔT values fall within 0.05 ms. Overall the ΔT distribution juxtaposed with STDP data shows that time-correlated APs from strongly connected neuronal pairs will preferentially potentiate the memristor, if biphasic sawtooth spikes converted from presynaptic and postsynaptic APs drive the bottom and top electrodes of the memristor. In this way, a neuronal connection information can be imprinted onto the memristor conductance change, ΔG. Critically, the STDP curve shape depends on the shape of input spikes. For example, when triangle input spikes are used (Fig. 1a), the corresponding STDP curve (Fig. 1a, black) is such that its window cannot be as effectively overlayed with the ΔT distribution, no matter how ΔT is time-compressed. This makes it more difficult to physically imprint neuronal connections onto the memristor. In summary, the sawtooth input spikes are chosen to optimize STDP in such a way that temporal correlations of APs of strongly connected neurons can effectively induce ΔG in the memristor. 

Figure 1b shows the aforementioned connection mapping results obtained by driving the memristor with 7 groups of intracellular neuronal recording data with each group containing 16 neuronal recording traces except one group containing 12 neuronal recording traces, with each AP in each recording trace converted into the sawtooth spike. As can be seen, from the 108 neuronal recording traces out of the 7 recording data groups, the memristor has mapped 55 neuronal connections and specified their connection strengths with a proper normalization, where the true number of connections is 61.
